item.title: Ian has moved to Harvard OEB
item.description: As of November 2017, I’ll be officially starting my new NSF-supported postdoctoral fellowship in the Department of Organismic and Evolutionary Biology at Harvard University. I’ll be based out of Harvard University Herbaria, where I’ll be associated with the lab of Charles C. Davis. I’ve been in the lab unofficially for almost a year, but it’s nice to finally be official!

item.title: 2017 MORA Snow Melt Forecasts

item.title: MORAclim Climate Maps
item.description: With support from the Northwest Climate Science Center, USGS Center for Integrated Data and Analytics, and the National Park Service, it’s my pleasure to introduce new gridded climate maps for Mt. Rainier National Park. These products are based on six years of monitoring air temperature and snow duration at hundreds of sites across Mt. Rainier using data from climate stations and low-cost distributed temperature sensors. For the first time, MORAclim gives us a detailed picture of how the Mountain’s topography and vegetation interact with the regional climate to produce a diverse set of microclimates.

item.title: 100 Years of Change at Mt. Rainier
item.description: I’ve always been fascinated by old photographs, so last year when I found an old panoramic photo of Mt. Rainier in Pat Pringle’s excellent Roadside Geology of Mount Rainier National Park and Vicinity I got really excited. The photo was taken in 1904 by W.P. Romans, and shows the northwest slopes of the mountain in the vicinity of Spray Park. The original is maintained by the Washington State Historical Society
